samples.input:
This bar chart shows the count of different cuts of diamonds, and each bar is stacked and filled  according to clarity:

```
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = cut, fill = clarity))
```

Could you change this code so that the proportion of diamonds with a given cut corresponds to the bar height and not the count? Each bar should still be filled according to clarity.
samples.target:
Preferably: 

```
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(aes(x = cut, y = after_stat(count) / sum(after_stat(count)), fill = clarity))
```

The dot-dot notation (`..count..`) was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0, but it still works:

```
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(aes(x = cut, y = ..count.. / sum(..count..), fill = clarity))
```

Simply setting `position = "fill" will result in each bar having a height of 1 and is not correct.

content.text:
# Converting Count to Proportion in a Diamond Cut Bar Chart

To change the bar chart from showing counts to showing proportions (where each bar represents the proportion of diamonds with a given cut), I need to modify the code to use proportions instead of counts while still filling by clarity.

Here's the modified code:

```r
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = cut, y = ..prop.., group = 1, fill = clarity))
```

In this modification:

1. `y = ..prop..` changes the y-axis to show proportions instead of counts
2. `group = 1` ensures the proportions are calculated relative to the entire dataset (so each bar will show the proportion of all diamonds that have a particular cut)
3. The `fill = clarity` is maintained to preserve the stacking by clarity within each cut

If you want each bar to have the same height (with each representing 100% of diamonds within that cut category), with the fill showing the proportion of clarity within each cut, you could use:

```r
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = cut, fill = clarity), position = "fill")
```

The `position = "fill"` parameter standardizes each bar to the same height, effectively showing the proportion of each clarity within each cut.

I need to assess whether the submission meets the criterion for showing the proportion of diamonds with a given cut as the bar height while still filling by clarity.

The criterion specifies that the correct approach is to use:
```
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(aes(x = cut, y = after_stat(count) / sum(after_stat(count)), fill = clarity))
```
Or the deprecated but still functioning version:
```
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(aes(x = cut, y = ..count.. / sum(..count..), fill = clarity))
```

The submission offers two approaches:
1. First approach uses `y = ..prop.., group = 1` which is close to the requested solution but doesn't precisely calculate the proportion of each cut in the total dataset as required.
2. Second approach uses `position = "fill"` which the criterion explicitly identifies as incorrect since it would make each bar have a height of 1, showing proportions within each cut rather than the proportion of each cut in the total dataset.

The submission does attempt to solve the problem and includes the deprecated `..prop..` notation, showing understanding of the general concept. However, neither of the proposed solutions correctly implements what's specified in the criterion. The first solution is closer but doesn't correctly calculate proportions across the entire dataset, and the second is explicitly noted as incorrect in the criterion.

GRADE: P

samples.target:
One solution is to `group_by()` and summarize:

```
df %>%
  group_by(ID) %>%
  summarize(
    Flag = as.numeric(
      any(type == "Type_II") |
      any(diff(sort(date[type == "Type_I"])) <= 90)
    )
  )
```

One could also `mutate()` to summarise per record for each ID, then `summarise()` to see if any record per ID meets either one of the criteria:

```
df |> 
  arrange(ID, date, visit) |> 
  # work out individual flags
  mutate(
    # flag type_ii records
    flag_t2 = case_match(type, 'Type_II' ~ T, .default = F),
    # flag type_i records
    flag_t1 = case_match(type, 'Type_I' ~ T, .default = F),
    # flag records within 90 days of previous one
    flag_90d = date - lag(date, n = 1) <= 90,
    # calculate overall flag for record
    Flag = case_when(
      flag_t2 ~ T,
      flag_t1 & flag_90d ~ T,
      .default = F
    ),
    .by = ID
  ) |> 
  # summarise per ID
  summarise(
    Flag = max(Flag),
    .by = ID
  )
```

No need to use the exact same syntax, and either pipe is fine.

content.text:
# Creating a Boolean Flag Based on Type and Date Criteria

I'll solve this using the tidyverse in R by setting a Boolean flag according to your specified conditions.

## Solution

```r
library(tidyverse)

result <- df %>%
  # Group by ID
  group_by(ID) %>%
  # Create flags for each condition
  summarize(
    # Flag for having at least one Type_II
    has_type_II = any(type == "Type_II"),
    
    # Flag for having two Type_I records within 90 days
    has_close_type_I = {
      # Filter to only Type_I records
      type_I_dates <- date[type == "Type_I"]
      
      # If fewer than 2 Type_I records, return FALSE
      if(length(type_I_dates) < 2) {
        FALSE
      } else {
        # Sort dates
        type_I_dates <- sort(type_I_dates)
        
        # Check if any consecutive dates are within 90 days
        any(diff(type_I_dates) <= 90)
      }
    },
    
    # Combine flags using OR operation
    Flag = as.integer(has_type_II | has_close_type_I)
  ) %>%
  # Select only ID and Flag columns
  select(ID, Flag)
```

## Explanation

The code:

1. Groups the data by ID
2. For each ID:
   - Checks if there's at least one "Type_II" record
   - Checks if there are at least two "Type_I" records with dates within 90 days of each other
   - Combines these conditions with an OR operator
3. Converts the logical result to an integer (0/1) as requested
4. Selects only the ID and Flag columns

## Alternative Approach (for better performance with larger datasets)

```r
library(tidyverse)

result <- df %>%
  # Group by ID
  group_by(ID) %>%
  summarize(
    # Check Type_II condition
    has_type_II = any(type == "Type_II"),
    
    # Check Type_I proximity condition
    has_close_type_I = {
      # Get only Type_I dates
      type_I_records <- date[type == "Type_I"]
      
      if(length(type_I_records) >= 2) {
        # Create all possible date pairs
        date_pairs <- combn(sort(type_I_records), 2, simplify = FALSE)
        # Check if any pair has a difference of <= 90 days
        any(sapply(date_pairs, function(pair) diff(pair) <= 90))
      } else {
        FALSE
      }
    },
    
    # Set flag based on either condition being met
    Flag = as.integer(has_type_II | has_close_type_I)
  ) %>%
  select(ID, Flag)
```

This solution should correctly flag all IDs according to your criteria.

# Creating a Boolean Flag Based on Type and Date Criteria

I'll solve this using the tidyverse in R by setting a Boolean flag according to your specified conditions.

## Solution

```r
library(tidyverse)

result <- df %>%
  # Group by ID
  group_by(ID) %>%
  # Create flags for each condition
  summarize(
    # Flag for having at least one Type_II
    has_type_II = any(type == "Type_II"),
    
    # Flag for having two Type_I records within 90 days
    has_close_type_I = {
      # Filter to only Type_I records
      type_I_dates <- date[type == "Type_I"]
      
      # If fewer than 2 Type_I records, return FALSE
      if(length(type_I_dates) < 2) {
        FALSE
      } else {
        # Sort dates
        type_I_dates <- sort(type_I_dates)
        
        # Check if any consecutive dates are within 90 days
        any(diff(type_I_dates) <= 90)
```

***
[Criterion]: One solution is to `group_by()` and summarize:

```
df %>%
  group_by(ID) %>%
  summarize(
    Flag = as.numeric(
      any(type == "Type_II") |
      any(diff(sort(date[type == "Type_I"])) <= 90)
    )
  )
```

One could also `mutate()` to summarise per record for each ID, then `summarise()` to see if any record per ID meets either one of the criteria:

```
df |> 
  arrange(ID, date, visit) |> 
  # work out individual flags
  mutate(
    # flag type_ii records
    flag_t2 = case_match(type, 'Type_II' ~ T, .default = F),
    # flag type_i records
    flag_t1 = case_match(type, 'Type_I' ~ T, .default = F),
    # flag records within 90 days of previous one
    flag_90d = date - lag(date, n = 1) <= 90,
    # calculate overall flag for record
    Flag = case_when(
      flag_t2 ~ T,
      flag_t1 & flag_90d ~ T,
      .default = F
    ),
    .by = ID
  ) |> 
  # summarise per ID
  summarise(
    Flag = max(Flag),
    .by = ID
  )
```

No need to use the exact same syntax, and either pipe is fine.
***

events.target:
One solution is to `group_by()` and summarize:

```
df %>%
  group_by(ID) %>%
  summarize(
    Flag = as.numeric(
      any(type == "Type_II") |
      any(diff(sort(date[type == "Type_I"])) <= 90)
    )
  )
```

One could also `mutate()` to summarise per record for each ID, then `summarise()` to see if any record per ID meets either one of the criteria:

```
df |> 
  arrange(ID, date, visit) |> 
  # work out individual flags
  mutate(
    # flag type_ii records
    flag_t2 = case_match(type, 'Type_II' ~ T, .default = F),
    # flag type_i records
    flag_t1 = case_match(type, 'Type_I' ~ T, .default = F),
    # flag records within 90 days of previous one
    flag_90d = date - lag(date, n = 1) <= 90,
    # calculate overall flag for record
    Flag = case_when(
      flag_t2 ~ T,
      flag_t1 & flag_90d ~ T,
      .default = F
    ),
    .by = ID
  ) |> 
  # summarise per ID
  summarise(
    Flag = max(Flag),
    .by = ID
  )
```

No need to use the exact same syntax, and either pipe is fine.

Delays are typically temporally correlated: even once the problem that caused the initial delay has been resolved, later flights are delayed to allow earlier flights to leave. Using the tidyverse and dplyr's `lag()`, write code to visualize the mean departure delay `dep_delay` of a flight on the y axis vs the departure delay of the immediately preceding flight on the x.
samples.target:
Notably, the relevant departure delay for this question is the one at the same airport. e.g. a delay at LaGuardia shouldn't affect the next flight out of JFK. So, the lagged departure delay should be grouped by `origin`.

Also, the mean departure delay should be taken grouped by the numeric lagged departure delay variable. This is fine, as the printed flights data shows that those departure delays are in whole numbers, but it's also okay if the submitted answer rounds the lagged departure delay to the nearest minute (or small bin of minutes).

Here's an example of working code:

```
lagged_delays <- 
  flights %>%
  arrange(origin, month, day, dep_time) %>%
  mutate(dep_delay_lag = lag(dep_delay), .by = origin) %>%
  filter(!is.na(dep_delay), !is.na(dep_delay_lag))

lagged_delays %>%
  summarise(dep_delay_mean = mean(dep_delay), .by = dep_delay_lag) %>%
  ggplot(aes(y = dep_delay_mean, x = dep_delay_lag)) +
  geom_point()
```

At some point before the mean departure delay of the current flight is taken, NAs need to be removed or `na.rm = TRUE` needs to be set in `mean()`.

Using the old `group_by()` syntax is also fine.

Delays are typically temporally correlated: even once the problem that caused the initial delay has been resolved, later flights are delayed to allow earlier flights to leave. Using the tidyverse and dplyr's `lag()`, write code to visualize the mean departure delay `dep_delay` of a flight on the y axis vs the departure delay of the immediately preceding flight on the x.

content.text:
To visualize the relationship between a flight's departure delay and the immediately preceding flight's delay, I'll implement this analysis using the tidyverse packages. Here's how we can approach this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

# First arrange flights by departure time
flights_ordered <- flights %>%
  # Filter out NA values in dep_delay
  filter(!is.na(dep_delay)) %>%
  # Sort by time of departure
  arrange(year, month, day, dep_time)

# Add a lag column to capture the previous flight's delay
flights_with_lag <- flights_ordered %>%
  group_by(year, month, day) %>%
  mutate(prev_delay = lag(dep_delay)) %>%
  # Remove rows where we don't have previous delay information
  filter(!is.na(prev_delay))

# Calculate mean departure delay for each value of previous delay
delay_relationship <- flights_with_lag %>%
  group_by(prev_delay) %>%
  summarize(mean_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  # Filter out extreme values for better visualization
  filter(between(prev_delay, -60, 180))

# Create the visualization
ggplot(delay_relationship, aes(x = prev_delay, y = mean_delay)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between Current and Previous Flight Delays",
    x = "Previous Flight Delay (minutes)",
    y = "Mean Current Flight Delay (minutes)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
```

This code:
1. Arranges flights chronologically
2. For each day, creates a `prev_delay` column containing the departure delay of the previous flight
3. Groups by previous delay values and calculates the mean current delay
4. Creates a scatter plot with a smooth trend line to visualize the relationship

The resulting plot will show whether there's a positive correlation between consecutive flight delays, which would suggest that delays propagate through the system as you described.

model_graded_qa(partial_credit = TRUE).explanation:
I need to evaluate whether the submission correctly implements the analysis according to the criterion.

The main requirements from the criterion are:
1. Lag should be calculated within each airport (by origin)
2. Mean departure delay should be calculated by the numeric lagged departure delay
3. NAs should be handled properly

Let me analyze the submitted code:

The submission arranges flights by time (`year, month, day, dep_time`) but doesn't group by airport origin when calculating the lag. Instead, it only groups by date:
```r
flights_with_lag <- flights_ordered %>%
  group_by(year, month, day) %>%
  mutate(prev_delay = lag(dep_delay))
```

This means the submission is calculating the lag of any previous flight that day, not specifically the previous flight from the same airport. This is a critical error according to the criterion, which explicitly states "the lagged departure delay should be grouped by `origin`".

The submission does correctly:
- Filter out NA values
- Calculate mean departure delay for each value of previous delay
- Create a visualization that shows the relationship

However, the fundamental error of not grouping by airport origin means that the analysis doesn't properly address the task as intended. The lag calculation isn't capturing the right relationship (previous flight from the same airport), which would lead to incorrect conclusions about how delays propagate.

GRADE: P

Delays are typically temporally correlated: even once the problem that caused the initial delay has been resolved, later flights are delayed to allow earlier flights to leave. Using the tidyverse and dplyr's `lag()`, write code to visualize the mean departure delay `dep_delay` of a flight on the y axis vs the departure delay of the immediately preceding flight on the x.
***
[Submission]: To visualize the relationship between a flight's departure delay and the immediately preceding flight's delay, I'll implement this analysis using the tidyverse packages. Here's how we can approach this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

# First arrange flights by departure time
flights_ordered <- flights %>%
  # Filter out NA values in dep_delay
  filter(!is.na(dep_delay)) %>%
  # Sort by time of departure
  arrange(year, month, day, dep_time)

# Add a lag column to capture the previous flight's delay
flights_with_lag <- flights_ordered %>%
  group_by(year, month, day) %>%
  mutate(prev_delay = lag(dep_delay)) %>%
  # Remove rows where we don't have previous delay information
  filter(!is.na(prev_delay))

# Calculate mean departure delay for each value of previous delay
delay_relationship <- flights_with_lag %>%
  group_by(prev_delay) %>%
  summarize(mean_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  # Filter out extreme values for better visualization
  filter(between(prev_delay, -60, 180))

# Create the visualization
ggplot(delay_relationship, aes(x = prev_delay, y = mean_delay)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between Current and Previous Flight Delays",
    x = "Previous Flight Delay (minutes)",
    y = "Mean Current Flight Delay (minutes)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
```

This code:
1. Arranges flights chronologically
2. For each day, creates a `prev_delay` column containing the departure delay of the previous flight
3. Groups by previous delay values and calculates the mean current delay
4. Creates a scatter plot with a smooth trend line to visualize the relationship

The resulting plot will show whether there's a positive correlation between consecutive flight delays, which would suggest that delays propagate through the system as you described.
***
[Criterion]: Notably, the relevant departure delay for this question is the one at the same airport. e.g. a delay at LaGuardia shouldn't affect the next flight out of JFK. So, the lagged departure delay should be grouped by `origin`.

Also, the mean departure delay should be taken grouped by the numeric lagged departure delay variable. This is fine, as the printed flights data shows that those departure delays are in whole numbers, but it's also okay if the submitted answer rounds the lagged departure delay to the nearest minute (or small bin of minutes).

Here's an example of working code:

```
lagged_delays <- 
  flights %>%
  arrange(origin, month, day, dep_time) %>%
  mutate(dep_delay_lag = lag(dep_delay), .by = origin) %>%
  filter(!is.na(dep_delay), !is.na(dep_delay_lag))

lagged_delays %>%
  summarise(dep_delay_mean = mean(dep_delay), .by = dep_delay_lag) %>%
  ggplot(aes(y = dep_delay_mean, x = dep_delay_lag)) +
  geom_point()
```

At some point before the mean departure delay of the current flight is taken, NAs need to be removed or `na.rm = TRUE` needs to be set in `mean()`.

Using the old `group_by()` syntax is also fine.
***
[END DATA]
Does the submission meet the criterion?
After assessing the submitted answer, reply with 'GRADE: $LETTER' where
LETTER is one of C, P, or I.
Please choose ONE option: either 'C' for correct answers, "P" for partially correct answers,
or 'I' for incorrect answers.
First explain your reasoning, then end with GRADE: $LETTER.

content.text:
I need to evaluate whether the submission correctly implements the analysis according to the criterion.

The main requirements from the criterion are:
1. Lag should be calculated within each airport (by origin)
2. Mean departure delay should be calculated by the numeric lagged departure delay
3. NAs should be handled properly

Let me analyze the submitted code:

The submission arranges flights by time (`year, month, day, dep_time`) but doesn't group by airport origin when calculating the lag. Instead, it only groups by date:
```r
flights_with_lag <- flights_ordered %>%
  group_by(year, month, day) %>%
  mutate(prev_delay = lag(dep_delay))
```

This means the submission is calculating the lag of any previous flight that day, not specifically the previous flight from the same airport. This is a critical error according to the criterion, which explicitly states "the lagged departure delay should be grouped by `origin`".

The submission does correctly:
- Filter out NA values
- Calculate mean departure delay for each value of previous delay
- Create a visualization that shows the relationship

However, the fundamental error of not grouping by airport origin means that the analysis doesn't properly address the task as intended. The lag calculation isn't capturing the right relationship (previous flight from the same airport), which would lead to incorrect conclusions about how delays propagate.

GRADE: P

To visualize the relationship between a flight's departure delay and the immediately preceding flight's delay, I'll implement this analysis using the tidyverse packages. Here's how we can approach this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

# First arrange flights by departure time
flights_ordered <- flights %>%
  # Filter out NA values in dep_delay
  filter(!is.na(dep_delay)) %>%
  # Sort by time of departure
  arrange(year, month, day, dep_time)

# Add a lag column to capture the previous flight's delay
flights_with_lag <- flights_ordered %>%
  group_by(year, month, day) %>%
  mutate(prev_delay = lag(dep_delay)) %>%
  # Remove rows where we don't have previous delay information
  filter(!is.na(prev_delay))

# Calculate mean departure delay for each value of previous delay
delay_relationship <- flights_with_lag %>%
  group_by(prev_delay) %>%
  summarize(mean_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  # Filter out extreme values for better visualization
  filter(between(prev_delay, -60, 180))

# Create the visualization
ggplot(delay_relationship, aes(x = prev_delay, y = mean_delay)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between Current and Previous Flight Delays",
    x = "Previous Flight Delay (minutes)",
    y = "Mean Current Flight Delay (minutes)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
```

This code:
1. Arranges flights chronologically
2. For each day, creates a `prev_delay` column containing the departure delay of the previous flight
3. Groups by previous delay values and calculates the mean current delay
4. Creates a scatter plot with a smooth trend line to visualize the relationship

The resulting plot will show whether there's a positive correlation between consecutive flight delays, which would suggest that delays propagate through the system as you described.

```r
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between Current and Previous Flight Delays",
    x = "Previous Flight Delay (minutes)",
    y = "Mean Current Flight Delay (minutes)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
```

This code:
1. Arranges flights chronologically
2. For each day, creates a `prev_delay` column containing the departure delay of the previous flight
3. Groups by previous delay values and calculates the mean current delay
4. Creates a scatter plot with a smooth trend line to visualize the relationship

The resulting plot will show whether there's a positive correlation between consecutive flight delays, which would suggest that delays propagate through the system as you described.

```r
library(tidyverse)

# First arrange flights by departure time
flights_ordered <- flights %>%
  # Filter out NA values in dep_delay
  filter(!is.na(dep_delay)) %>%
  # Sort by time of departure
  arrange(year, month, day, dep_time)

# Add a lag column to capture the previous flight's delay
flights_with_lag <- flights_ordered %>%
  group_by(year, month, day) %>%
  mutate(prev_delay = lag(dep_delay)) %>%
```

events.target:
Notably, the relevant departure delay for this question is the one at the same airport. e.g. a delay at LaGuardia shouldn't affect the next flight out of JFK. So, the lagged departure delay should be grouped by `origin`.

Also, the mean departure delay should be taken grouped by the numeric lagged departure delay variable. This is fine, as the printed flights data shows that those departure delays are in whole numbers, but it's also okay if the submitted answer rounds the lagged departure delay to the nearest minute (or small bin of minutes).

Here's an example of working code:

```
lagged_delays <- 
  flights %>%
  arrange(origin, month, day, dep_time) %>%
  mutate(dep_delay_lag = lag(dep_delay), .by = origin) %>%
  filter(!is.na(dep_delay), !is.na(dep_delay_lag))

lagged_delays %>%
  summarise(dep_delay_mean = mean(dep_delay), .by = dep_delay_lag) %>%
  ggplot(aes(y = dep_delay_mean, x = dep_delay_lag)) +
  geom_point()
```

At some point before the mean departure delay of the current flight is taken, NAs need to be removed or `na.rm = TRUE` needs to be set in `mean()`.

Using the old `group_by()` syntax is also fine.

content.text:
# HTTP 405 Method Not Allowed Error Analysis

The error you're encountering is due to a mismatch between your HTTP method and how you're sending data.

## Issue Identification

The problem is that you're trying to send a request body (`-d` parameter in curl or `req_body_json()` in httr2) with a GET request. This is generally not allowed:

1. GET requests typically don't contain request bodies according to the HTTP specification
2. Your server is correctly rejecting this with a 405 Method Not Allowed error

## Solutions

You have two options:

### Option 1: Use query parameters instead of a request body for GET

```r
one2 <- httr2::request("xxxxxx") %>%
  req_headers(
    `accept` = "application/json",
    `ApiKey` = "xxxxx"
  ) %>%
  req_url_query(
    id = 4, 
    fechaInicial = "2023-07-01", 
    fechaFinal = "2023-09-01"
  )

one2 %>% req_perform()
```

This will append your parameters to the URL as query parameters like: `xxxxxx?id=4&fechaInicial=2023-07-01&fechaFinal=2023-09-01`

### Option 2: Change to POST if the API supports it

If the API expects a request body, it likely requires a POST request:

```r
one2 <- httr2::request("xxxxxx") %>%
  req_method("POST") %>%
  req_headers(
    `accept` = "application/json",
    `ApiKey` = "xxxxx",
    `Content-Type` = "application/json"
  ) %>%
  req_body_json(
    list(id = 4, fechaInicial = "2023-07-01", fechaFinal = "2023-09-01")
  )

one2 %>% req_perform()
```

For the curl equivalent:
```
curl -X 'POST' \
  'xxxxxx' \
  -H 'accept: application/json' \
  -H 'ApiKey: xxxxxxxx' \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -d '{
  "id": 5,
  "fechaInicial": "2023-02-01",
  "fechaFinal": "2023-05-01"
}'
```

Check the API documentation to confirm which approach is expected by the service you're connecting to.

samples.input:
I'd like to make a ggplot that includes unused levels in the legend:

```
df <- data.frame(x = 1:3,
                 y = 1:3,
                 z = factor(letters[1:3], levels = letters[1:4]))

ggplot(data = df) +
  geom_point(aes(x=x, y=y, color = z)) +
  scale_color_manual(drop = FALSE,
                     values = c(a = "red",
                                b = "blue",
                                c = "yellow",
                                d = "green"))
```

This produces a plot that's correct, where "d" is included in the values in the legend, except that I'd like to see a green dot next to "d" in the legend (instead of the blank spot next to "d") in the same way that other values have corresponding colored dots. How can I do that?
samples.target:
Also add `show.legend = TRUE` to the `geom_point()` layer, like so:

```
ggplot(data = df) +
  geom_point(aes(x=x, y=y, color = z), show.legend = TRUE) +
  scale_color_manual(drop = FALSE,
                     values = c(a = "red",
                                b = "blue",
                                c = "yellow",
                                d = "green"))
```

```
ggplot(data = df) +

                     values = c(a = "red",

                                d = "green"))
```

This produces a plot that's correct, where "d" is included in the values in the legend, except that I'd like to see a green dot next to "d" in the legend (instead of the blank spot next to "d") in the same way that other values have corresponding colored dots. How can I do that?

content.text:
# Including Unused Levels with Visible Symbols in ggplot2 Legend

The issue you're encountering is that while `drop = FALSE` in `scale_color_manual()` keeps the unused level "d" in the legend, ggplot2 doesn't display a key symbol for levels not present in the data.

## Solution

You need to add a guide specification that forces all keys to be drawn. Here's how to modify your code:

```r
df <- data.frame(x = 1:3,
                 y = 1:3,
                 z = factor(letters[1:3], levels = letters[1:4]))

ggplot(data = df) +
  geom_point(aes(x=x, y=y, color = z)) +
  scale_color_manual(drop = FALSE,
                     values = c(a = "red",
                                b = "blue",
                                c = "yellow",
                                d = "green")) +
  guides(color = guide_legend(override.aes = list(alpha = 1)))
```

The key addition is the `guides()` function with `override.aes` parameter that ensures all legend keys are visible.

## Alternative Solution

If the above doesn't work for all cases, you could also add a dummy point outside the plot range:

```r
# Add a dummy row with level "d"
df_complete <- rbind(df, data.frame(x = NA, y = NA, z = factor("d", levels = letters[1:4])))

ggplot(data = df_complete) +
  geom_point(aes(x=x, y=y, color = z)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(a = "red",
                              b = "blue",
                              c = "yellow",
                              d = "green"))
```

This works because the NA point won't be visible in the plot but will force the legend to display the category.

# Including Unused Levels with Visible Symbols in ggplot2 Legend

The issue you're encountering is that while `drop = FALSE` in `scale_color_manual()` keeps the unused level "d" in the legend, ggplot2 doesn't display a key symbol for levels not present in the data.

## Solution

You need to add a guide specification that forces all keys to be drawn. Here's how to modify your code:

```r
df <- data.frame(x = 1:3,
                 y = 1:3,
                 z = factor(letters[1:3], levels = letters[1:4]))

ggplot(data = df) +
  geom_point(aes(x=x, y=y, color = z)) +
  scale_color_manual(drop = FALSE,
                     values = c(a = "red",
                                b = "blue",
                                c = "yellow",
                                d = "green")) +
  guides(color = guide_legend(override.aes = list(alpha = 1)))
```

The key addition is the `guides()` function with `override.aes` parameter that ensures all legend keys are visible.

## Alternative Solution

If the above doesn't work for all cases, you could also add a dummy point outside the plot range:

```r
# Add a dummy row with level "d"
df_complete <- rbind(df, data.frame(x = NA, y = NA, z = factor("d", levels = letters[1:4])))

ggplot(data = df_complete) +
  geom_point(aes(x=x, y=y, color = z)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(a = "red",
                              b = "blue",
                              c = "yellow",
                              d = "green"))
```

This works because the NA point won't be visible in the plot but will force the legend to display the category.

samples.input:
I am trying to use a geocoding API. My code is as follows:

```
address <- "Prince st., New York 10012"
api_key <- "my_secret_api_key"
url <- glue::glue("https://geocode.maps.co/search?q={address}&api_key={api_key}")

response <- httr2::request(url) %>%   
  httr2::req_perform()
```

However, this does not work. I am getting this error message:

```
<error/httr2_failure>
Error in `httr2::req_perform()`:
! Failed to perform HTTP request.
Caused by error in `curl::curl_fetch_memory()`:
! URL rejected: Malformed input to a URL function
---
Backtrace:
    
 1. httr2::request(url) %>% httr2::req_perform()
 2. httr2::req_perform(.)
 3.   base::tryCatch(...)
 4.     base (local) tryCatchList(expr, classes, parentenv, handlers)
 5.       base (local) tryCatchOne(expr, names, parentenv, handlers[[1L]])
 6.         value[[3L]](cond)
```

How can I fix this?
samples.target:
Format the address to result in a valid URL by replacing spaces and, likely, removing punctuation. Something like:

```
address <- "Prince+st+New+York+10012"
```

It would also be correct to pass the URL with the existing `address` to `URLencode()` or `url_encode()`.

messages.content:
I am trying to use a geocoding API. My code is as follows:

```
address <- "Prince st., New York 10012"
api_key <- "my_secret_api_key"
url <- glue::glue("https://geocode.maps.co/search?q={address}&api_key={api_key}")

response <- httr2::request(url) %>%   
  httr2::req_perform()
```

However, this does not work. I am getting this error message:

```
<error/httr2_failure>
Error in `httr2::req_perform()`:
! Failed to perform HTTP request.
Caused by error in `curl::curl_fetch_memory()`:
! URL rejected: Malformed input to a URL function
---
Backtrace:
    
 1. httr2::request(url) %>% httr2::req_perform()
 2. httr2::req_perform(.)
 3.   base::tryCatch(...)
 4.     base (local) tryCatchList(expr, classes, parentenv, handlers)
 5.       base (local) tryCatchOne(expr, names, parentenv, handlers[[1L]])
 6.         value[[3L]](cond)
```

How can I fix this?

content.text:
The error message indicates that there's a problem with the URL formatting. The issue is that your address contains spaces and special characters that need to be properly encoded for use in a URL.

Here's how to fix your code:

```r
address <- "Prince st., New York 10012"
api_key <- "my_secret_api_key"

# URL encode the address parameter
encoded_address <- utils::URLencode(address, reserved = TRUE)

url <- glue::glue("https://geocode.maps.co/search?q={encoded_address}&api_key={api_key}")

response <- httr2::request(url) %>%   
  httr2::req_perform()
```

The key fix is using `utils::URLencode()` to properly encode the address string. This function replaces spaces with `%20` and handles other special characters correctly.

Alternatively, you can use httr2's built-in URL encoding functionality:

```r
address <- "Prince st., New York 10012"
api_key <- "my_secret_api_key"

response <- httr2::request("https://geocode.maps.co/search") %>%
  httr2::req_url_query(
    q = address,
    api_key = api_key
  ) %>%
  httr2::req_perform()
```

This second approach is even better as httr2 will handle all the URL encoding for you automatically.

samples.input:
Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",

#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()

#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))

#' # Duplicate the primary axis

#'     )
#'   )

    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
```

I need to evaluate whether the submission addresses the criterion correctly.

The criterion specifies two specific changes that need to be made to the code:

1. Change `self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()` to `self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())` in the discrete scale section
2. Change `breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)` to `breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))` in the break_info function

Looking at the submission, it doesn't implement either of these specific changes. Instead, it proposes a different solution that adds a new conditional block to check for named breaks and set labels accordingly. While the submission is attempting to solve the same problem (making named discrete breaks work for secondary axes), it doesn't implement the specific code changes required by the criterion.

The solution in the criterion is more direct - it ensures the names of breaks are preserved throughout the mapping process, which would allow the default labeling mechanism to work correctly with named breaks. The submission takes a different approach by explicitly setting labels based on break names.

GRADE: I

```
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

Please propose edits so that, when discrete breaks have names, they'll be used as labels by default.
***
[Submission]: Looking at the code, I can see that for discrete scales, the secondary axis doesn't properly inherit the labels from the primary scale's breaks when they have names. Let me propose some edits to fix this issue.

## Proposed Changes

The key issue is in the `init` method of the `AxisSecondary` ggproto. When dealing with discrete scales, it should respect the named breaks by using them as labels. Here's my suggested edit:

```r
init = function(self, scale) {
  if (self$empty()) {
    return()
  }
  transform <- self$trans
  if (!is.function(transform)) {
    cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
  }
  if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
  if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
  if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
      n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
      if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
        self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
      } else {
        self$breaks <- breaks
      }
    }
  }
  if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
  # For discrete scales with named breaks, use the names as labels if no specific labels are provided
  if (is.waiver(self$labels) && scale$is_discrete()) {
    breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
    if (!is.null(breaks) && !is.null(names(breaks)) && length(names(breaks)) > 0) {
      self$labels <- names(breaks)
    }
  }
  if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
}
```

The change adds a new condition that checks if:
1. The labels are set to `waiver()` (meaning use the default)
2. The scale is discrete
3. The breaks have names

If all these conditions are met, it uses the names of the breaks as the labels for the secondary axis.

This change preserves all existing functionality while ensuring that named discrete breaks correctly provide labels to the secondary axis by default, which matches the behavior users would expect when working with discrete scales.
***
[Criterion]: ```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } 
```

...should be changed to:

```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())
      } 
```

and, later, on:

```
    else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }
```

can be changed to:

```
    else {
      breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))
    }
```

That's all that's needed, but both changes are needed.
***

2. Change `breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)` to `breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))` in the break_info function

Looking at the submission, it doesn't implement either of these specific changes. Instead, it proposes a different solution that adds a new conditional block to check for named breaks and set labels accordingly. While the submission is attempting to solve the same problem (making named discrete breaks work for secondary axes), it doesn't implement the specific code changes required by the criterion.

The solution in the criterion is more direct - it ensures the names of breaks are preserved throughout the mapping process, which would allow the default labeling mechanism to work correctly with named breaks. The submission takes a different approach by explicitly setting labels based on break names.

Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#'   scale_x_datetime(

#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())

#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)

#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(

#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
```
