  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

}

          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {

  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {

    # Get scale's original range before transformation

    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    duplicates <- c(

      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)

#'

#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)

#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'

#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.

#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'

#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.

#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())

#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand

#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:

#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {

#' @rdname sec_axis

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {

#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay` values among those that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to include only tailnums with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by the proportion of NA arr_delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with the highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select only the tailnum column for the final result
  select(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by `tailnum`
2. For each `tailnum`, calculates:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
   - The proportion of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
3. Filters to include only `tailnum`s with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts in descending order by the proportion of NA values
5. Takes the first row (the `tailnum` with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the `tailnum` column

The result will be the `tailnum` that meets your criteria.

```

1. Groups the flights data by `tailnum`
2. For each `tailnum`, calculates:
   - The total number of flights

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

  summarize(

  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```

  filter(n() > 100) %>%

  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to include only tailnums with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by the proportion of NA arr_delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with the highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select only the tailnum column for the final result
  select(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by `tailnum`
2. For each `tailnum`, calculates:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
   - The proportion of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
3. Filters to include only `tailnum`s with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts in descending order by the proportion of NA values
5. Takes the first row (the `tailnum` with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the `tailnum` column

The result will be the `tailnum` that meets your criteria.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

content.text:
# Error with `.by` inside `mutate()`

The error you're seeing occurs because you're incorrectly specifying the `.by` parameter inside `mutate()`. The syntax for using `.by` is different from how you've written it.

## How to fix it

Instead of using `.by = c(id, date)`, you need to pass it as a separate argument to `mutate()`. Here are the correct ways to use it:

### Option 1: Use `.by` as a separate argument

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    .by = c(id, date)
  )
```

### Option 2: Use `by` parameter (dplyr 1.1.0+)

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    by = c(id, date)
  )
```

The error occurs because when you put `by = c(id, date)` inside the list of expressions to compute, dplyr tries to create a new column called "by" rather than using it as a grouping parameter.

## Common mistake example

```r
# INCORRECT 
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    by = c(id, date)  # This creates a column called "by" instead of grouping
  )

# CORRECT 
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    .by = c(id, date)  # This is a parameter to mutate(), not a new column
  )
```

Let me know if you have any questions about this syntax!

# Error with `.by` inside `mutate()`

The error you're seeing occurs because you're incorrectly specifying the `.by` parameter inside `mutate()`. The syntax for using `.by` is different from how you've written it.

## How to fix it

Instead of using `.by = c(id, date)`, you need to pass it as a separate argument to `mutate()`. Here are the correct ways to use it:

### Option 1: Use `.by` as a separate argument

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    .by = c(id, date)
  )
```

### Option 2: Use `by` parameter (dplyr 1.1.0+)

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    by = c(id, date)
  )
```

The error occurs because when you put `by = c(id, date)` inside the list of expressions to compute, dplyr tries to create a new column called "by" rather than using it as a grouping parameter.

## Common mistake example

```r
# INCORRECT 
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    by = c(id, date)  # This creates a column called "by" instead of grouping
  )

# CORRECT 
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    .by = c(id, date)  # This is a parameter to mutate(), not a new column
  )
```

Let me know if you have any questions about this syntax!

samples.input:
Add a `name` argument after `dataset` that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling env.

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.
samples.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

I'll modify the `task_create` function to add a `name` argument that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling environment, and store it as a `name` attribute in the result.

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

This implementation:

1. Adds a new `name` parameter right after `dataset`
2. Uses `deparse(substitute(dataset))` as the default value to capture the variable name of the dataset argument
3. Stores the name as an attribute in the result structure with `attr(res, "name") <- name`

With this change, when you call `x <- task_create(dataset = eval)`, `attr(x, "name")` would return `"eval"`.

I'll evaluate the submitted answer against the criterion.

The submission correctly addresses most of the requirements:

1.  It adds a `name` parameter right after `dataset` with the correct default value `deparse(substitute(dataset))`.
2.  It properly sets the name attribute with `attr(res, "name") <- name`.
3.  It maintains the rest of the original function without unnecessary changes.

However, there is one important deficiency:

 It doesn't include the `force(name)` call before `check_dataset(dataset)`. This is specifically mentioned in the criterion as necessary to ensure the substitution works correctly.

The `force()` call is important because it ensures that the name is evaluated immediately, capturing the original variable name before any other evaluations happen. Without this line, in some contexts the substitution might not work as expected.

Since the solution implements most requirements correctly but is missing the critical `force(name)` line, I would consider it partially correct.

GRADE: P

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

samples.input: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?
samples.target: Either set `geom_jitter(height = 0)` or `geom_point(position = position_jitter(height = 0))`.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
# Using jitter in ggplot2 only on the x-axis

To jitter points in ggplot2 only along the x-axis (while keeping the y-values unchanged), you have two main options:

## Option 1: Use position_jitter() with width parameter

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

The key is setting `height = 0` to prevent any vertical jittering.

## Option 2: Use geom_jitter() with width parameter

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

## Additional tips:

- Adjust the `width` parameter to control the amount of horizontal jittering
- For reproducible jitter, set a seed before plotting: `set.seed(123)`
- You can combine jittering with other aesthetics:
  ```r
  ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable, color = group)) +
    geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
  ```

Would you like to see a complete example with sample data?

The criterion states that the issue is related to lazy evaluation of the `name` parameter, where `dataset` is being evaluated before `name`. The criterion suggests that `name` needs to be evaluated early in the function using something like `force(name)`.

The submitted answer doesn't correctly identify this as a lazy evaluation issue. Instead, it proposes two completely different approaches:

1. Option 1: Search the calling environment for an object that matches the dataset

task_create <- function(

[Submission]: # Fixing the `name` Parameter in `task_create()`

The issue you're experiencing happens because `deparse(substitute(dataset))` doesn't work as expected when `dataset` is already evaluated before being passed to the function.

## Solution

Replace your current implementation with one of these approaches:

### Option 1: Using rlang to capture the expression

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Get the expression if name is NULL
  if (is.null(name)) {
    # Get the caller environment
    caller_env <- parent.frame()
    
    # Try to find the name of the object passed as dataset
    for (obj_name in ls(caller_env)) {
      if (identical(get(obj_name, envir = caller_env), dataset)) {
        name <- obj_name
        break
      }
    }
    
    # If no matching name found, use a default
    if (is.null(name)) {
      name <- "unnamed_dataset"
    }
  }
  
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

### Option 2: Using rlang with explicit capture

```r
# Make sure to add rlang to your imports
library(rlang)

task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Use the caller environment to get the name
  if (is.null(name)) {
    call <- sys.call()
    arg_expr <- match.call()$dataset
    
    if (!is.null(arg_expr) && is.name(arg_expr)) {
      name <- as.character(arg_expr)
    } else {
      name <- "unnamed_dataset"
    }
  }
  
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

## Why This Works

The original issue occurs because:

1. `substitute(dataset)` captures the already-evaluated value of `dataset`
2. `deparse()` then converts this complex object to a string representation

The fixes work by either:
- Finding the name of the object in the calling environment that matches the dataset
- Capturing the actual expression used to call the function and extracting the argument name

With these approaches, when you run `task_create(dataset = simple_addition)`, the name will correctly be set to "simple_addition".

I'll evaluate whether the submitted answer correctly identifies the issue of maintaining proper hierarchical namespaces in nested Shiny modules.

The submission correctly identifies the core issue - that when working with nested Shiny modules, proper namespace handling is crucial, especially for dynamically generated UI elements. The key insight is that instead of creating a new namespace with `NS(id)` inside the moduleServer function, we should use `session$ns` which maintains the proper hierarchical relationship with parent modules.

However, there's a slight discrepancy in how the submission implements the fix. In the fixed code, the submission shows:

```r
innerServer <- function(id){
  moduleServer(id, function(input, output, session) {
    # Use session$ns instead of NS(id) when inside moduleServer
    ...
```

But doesn't explicitly show replacing `ns <- NS(id)` with `ns <- session$ns` as specified in the criterion. Instead, it directly uses `session$ns` in the renderUI function while keeping the original code structure. 

Also, the submission adds changes to the outerServer function that weren't identified in the criterion as part of the issue (using `session$ns("inner1")` instead of just `"inner1"`). This change is actually unnecessary and could introduce other issues.

While the submission correctly identifies that `session$ns` should be used instead of `NS(id)` inside the moduleServer function, it doesn't implement the fix exactly as specified in the criterion.

GRADE: P

Also, the submission adds changes to the outerServer function that weren't identified in the criterion as part of the issue (using `session$ns("inner1")` instead of just `"inner1"`). This change is actually unnecessary and could introduce other issues.

content.text:
# Understanding Your Package Dependency Issue

This looks like a mismatch between how your package dependency is declared and how `pkgdown` and `pak` are trying to resolve it. Let me explain what's happening and how to fix it.

## The Problem

1. Your package depends on `spatialstuff` (as declared in the package namespace)
2. However, the actual repository name is `org/spatial-Stuff` (different casing and with a hyphen)
3. The `pkgdown` workflow can't find a package called `spatialstuff` when trying to build the documentation

## Solution

The issue is that the `Remotes:` field needs to explicitly map the package name to the GitHub repository. You need to use the `package=repository` syntax:

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
```

This tells R package managers that the package named `spatialstuff` (as referenced in your `Imports:`) should be installed from the GitHub repository `org/spatial-Stuff`.

## Why This Happens

Without the explicit mapping, package managers assume that:
- The package name in the repository matches the package name in `Imports:`
- The GitHub repository name matches the package name

When these don't align (as in your case), you need to provide the explicit mapping.

## Additional Considerations

- Make sure the package name in the `DESCRIPTION` file inside the `org/spatial-Stuff` repository is actually `spatialstuff`
- You might want to pin a specific version with `org/spatial-Stuff@v1.2.3` if needed for stability

Does this help explain the issue you're encountering?

# Understanding Your Package Dependency Issue

This looks like a mismatch between how your package dependency is declared and how `pkgdown` and `pak` are trying to resolve it. Let me explain what's happening and how to fix it.

## The Problem

1. Your package depends on `spatialstuff` (as declared in the package namespace)
2. However, the actual repository name is `org/spatial-Stuff` (different casing and with a hyphen)
3. The `pkgdown` workflow can't find a package called `spatialstuff` when trying to build the documentation

## Solution

The issue is that the `Remotes:` field needs to explicitly map the package name to the GitHub repository. You need to use the `package=repository` syntax:

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
```

This tells R package managers that the package named `spatialstuff` (as referenced in your `Imports:`) should be installed from the GitHub repository `org/spatial-Stuff`.

## Why This Happens

Without the explicit mapping, package managers assume that:
- The package name in the repository matches the package name in `Imports:`
- The GitHub repository name matches the package name

When these don't align (as in your case), you need to provide the explicit mapping.

## Additional Considerations

- Make sure the package name in the `DESCRIPTION` file inside the `org/spatial-Stuff` repository is actually `spatialstuff`
- You might want to pin a specific version with `org/spatial-Stuff@v1.2.3` if needed for stability

Does this help explain the issue you're encountering?

[Task]: I see:

Error:

generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {

    ch <- chat$clone()

    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

How can I fix it?
***
[Submission]: The error you're encountering is due to a recursive reference in the default argument. When you set a default value for an argument that involves computation (like `chat = ellmer::chat_claude()`), R tries to evaluate this when the function is defined.

Here's how to fix your function:

```r
generate <- function(chat = NULL) {
  
  function(input, chat_obj = chat) {
    # Initialize chat if it's NULL
    if (is.null(chat_obj)) {
      chat_obj <- ellmer::chat_claude()
    }
    
    ch <- chat_obj$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

The key changes are:

1. Set the default value of `chat` to `NULL` in the outer function
2. Use a different parameter name in the inner function (`chat_obj`) to avoid confusion
3. Only create a new chat object when needed

This way, the default argument doesn't try to evaluate `ellmer::chat_claude()` at function definition time, avoiding the recursive reference problem.
***
[Criterion]: It can be fixed by changing the name of the `chat` argument in one of the functions or assigning the `chat` object in the outer function to a different variable name internally and then supplying that renamed object as the default to the inner function.
***
[END DATA]

)
```

* There should be a call to `cli::cli_abort()`.
* There should be no `paste0()`s left in the call. If the string is split up into multiple lines, it can also end with `\` or `\\`.

```r
cli::cli_abort(
  "The workflow has arguments to be tuned that are missing {?some/a} parameter object{?s}: {.arg {pset$id[!params]}}"
)

I see this warning and error when I launch my shiny app:

```
Listening on http://127.0.0.1:3516
Warning: Error in $: Can't read output 'plot'
  46: <Anonymous>
  45: signalCondition
  44: signal_abort
  43: rlang::abort
  42: $.shinyoutput
  40: server [#2]
   3: runApp
   2: print.shiny.appobj
   1: <Anonymous>
Error in output$plot : Can't read output 'plot'
```

Here's the app's code:

```
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
ckd_condition <- reactive({
  input$condition
})

visit_threshold <- reactive({
  input$visit_threshold
})

filtered_data <- reactive({
  Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
    filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition, VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold)
})

# Create a linear model and visualization
output$plot <- renderPlot({
  validate(
    need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
    need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
  )
                                 # Filter the data based on the user's input
  data <- filtered_data()
  
                                 # Create a linear model
  lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
  
                                 # Create a plot of the linear model
  ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
    geom_point() + 
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
    labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
})

# Create a dropdown menu for the user to select the CKD condition level
# and a numeric input field for the visit threshold
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = function(input, output) {
  output$plot
})
```

How do I fix it?

    validate(

                                   # Filter the data based on the user's input

                                   # Create a linear model

      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```
